block.p: Bush Again Rejects Calls For Immediate Iraq Pullout President Bush, faced with mounting casualties and signs of diminished support for the war, said that while the United States was making progress in Iraq, it was too soon to say when the number of American troops could be reduced.
One of Iraq's most powerful Shiite politicians backed demands for the formation of a semi-independent region in the oil-rich south, adding fresh turmoil to the drafting of the new constitution.

Guarded Optimism in Gaza Israel's planned evacuation of Jewish settlers and soldiers from the Gaza Strip has generated optimism among Gazans. But the good cheer, they say, is tempered by the belief that Israel will continue to wield control over Gaza from the outside.

U.N. Voices Concern Over Iran The United Nations nuclear agency expressed concern about Iran's nuclear program and agreed on a resolution that ''urges Iran to re-establish full suspension of all enrichment-related activities.''
Britain to Deport 10 Foreigners Charles Clarke, the home secretary of Britain, announced that 10 foreigners seen as a ''threat to national security'' had been seized and would be deported.
U.S. Blamed in Afghans' Deaths Four civilians were killed several days ago in a village in southern Afghanistan in an episode that survivors described as a bombing by an American plane.

9 Challengers to Face Mubarak Egypt's presidential commission announced that nine candidates would be able to challenge President Hosni Mubarak in the nation's first multicandidate race for the office.

Lobbyist, DeLay Friend,Is Indicted in Fraud Case Jack Abramoff, the Republican lobbyist at the center of ethics questions involving his friend Tom DeLay, the House majority leader, was indicted on unrelated fraud charges involving his purchase of gambling boats from a man who was killed amid bitter wrangling over the sale.

A political action committee run by Mr. DeLay broke election laws by paying expenses from the wrong account, increasing the amount of money it could spend on Congressional races, a Federal Election Commission audit found.

Iraq Photos' Release Opposed Senior Pentagon officials opposed the release of photographs and videotapes of the abuse of detainees at Abu Ghraib prison in Iraq, arguing they would incite public opinion in the Muslim world and put the lives of American soldiers at risk.
Air Guard Changes Supported The Justice Department concluded that the Pentagon has the authority to move Air National Guard units without the consent of governors, several of whom oppose the changes.

F.B.I. Terror Warning Doubted F.B.I. counterterrorism analysts warned of possible terrorist attacks in New York, Los Angeles and Chicago near the anniversary of Sept. 11, but some officials expressed skepticism about the seriousness of the threat. A13

New Data on Global Warming Scientists demonstrated that the atmosphere's lowest layer has warmed over the last two decades, contradicting earlier data and laying to rest a common argument against the threat of global warming.

N.Y.U. Medical School To Get $105 Million Gift A scientist at the New York University School of Medicine who made a fortune on a blockbuster drug used to treat Crohn's disease will donate $105 million to his professional home, one of the largest gifts ever given to a school or health care institution in New York.

10 Rare Gold Pieces Found The United States Mint announced that it had recovered 10 more of its fabled 1933 Double Eagle $20 gold pieces and stored them in Fort Knox. But the family that sought to authenticate them at the Mint claims that the government had no right to take them.

City Unveiling 9/11 Records Official New York City records from Sept. 11, 2001, including more than 12,000 pages of oral histories rendered in the voices of 503 firefighters, paramedics and emergency medical technicians, are to be made public today.

Priest Resigns Amid Scandal The rector of St. Patrick's Cathedral, resigned amid accusations that he was having an affair with his personal secretary, a married mother of two who is 33 years his junior.

A star of the Negro baseball leagues, whose prowess on the pitching mound and behind the plate inspired Damon Runyon to nickname him Double Duty, he was 103.

Paperbacks Get Bigger The Penguin Group and Simon & Schuster, two of the biggest publishers of mass-market titles, have begun issuing paperbacks in a bigger size withlarger type and more space between lines, in hopes of increasing sales among baby boomers who are finding it harder to read the small type of mass-market paperbacks. A1

Sullivan Gets Five Years A federal judge sentenced Scott D. Sullivan, who acknowledged his leading role in WorldCom's $11 billion accounting fraud, to five years in prison -- a fifth of what sentencing guidelines had suggested and a striking example of the benefit of working with government prosecutors.

Guilty Plea in Shelter Case An investigation by federal prosecutors into sales of questionable tax shelters took a turn as a former bank executive, Domenick DeGiorgio, pleaded guilty to charges of conspiracy, fraud and tax evasion. C1
Another High for Crude Oil For the third time this week, crude oil prices raced to a new high. C7
